TEXT: The first applicant , PERSON , who has NORP and NORP nationality and was born in DATE , lodged the application with the ORG on her own behalf and on behalf of her daughter , PERSON ( the second applicant ) , who has NORP , NORP and NORP nationality and was born in DATE in GPE ( GPE ) . The applicants are currently living in GPE .

They were represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , Mr J. PERSON , Mr PERSON and PERSON , of ORG , and assisted at the hearing by Mr PERSON , of ORG , and Ms NORP PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .
The third - party intervener in the case , Mr PERSON , of PERSON - NORP nationality and father of the second applicant , was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
He was represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , of FAC , assisted at the hearing by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE , and Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by those appearing before the ORG , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE PERSON married Mr Chelouche . The civil wedding took place before the NORP consular authorities in GPE . A NORP wedding ceremony also took place in the same city .

The couple apparently intended to settle permanently in GPE , although Mr Chelouche ’s professional activities often kept him in GPE and PERSON often went to GPE , either for work purposes or to visit her family .
As she never sought to acquire NORP nationality , the first applicant used to stay in GPE on DATE tourist visas issued by the NORP consulate in GPE .
On DATE the second applicant was born in GPE . The couple continued travelling between the CARDINAL countries , however . The child was always accompanied by her mother .
As time went by the couple ’s relationship deteriorated .
On DATE the applicants went to GPE for DATE . The plan was that they would stay there for DATE . PERSON put off the return date a number of times , however , and ultimately decided to remain in GPE .
On DATE the first applicant filed a divorce petition ( case no . DATE - CARDINAL ) with the single judge of the ORG in GPE ( “ the ORG ” ) .
On DATE the ORG awarded PERSON interim custody of her daughter . Up until then PERSON and Mr Chelouche had had joint custody of their daughter .

On DATE , having been informed of the situation , PERSON in turn petitioned for divorce in ORG ( ORG – “ the ORG ” ) , composed of CARDINAL religious judges ( dayanim ) . PERSON asked for the issue of custody of his daughter to be determined at the same time as that of the religious dissolution of the marriage . That request conferred full jurisdiction ipso jure on ORG to rule on the issue of custody rights .
In his pleadings PERSON expressed the fear that his daughter would emigrate from GPE , which , judging by his wife ’s conduct , would sever all his ties with his daughter .
On DATE ORG made CARDINAL orders .

In the first one it ordered PERSON to bring her daughter back to GPE within DATE , failing which her action would be deemed “ wrongful removal of the child ” within the meaning of LAW ( “ LAW ) . The first applicant was informed of the order by telephone , and subsequently by fax and mail , and was given DATE in which to reply .

Before giving its ruling , ORG found it to be established that after their marriage the couple had elected GPE as the family ’s fixed place of residence , and that PERSON , although a NORP national , had continually lived in GPE , had obtained a driving licence and work permit in that country and had opened a bank account there . Pointing out that the child was a minor , of NORP nationality and resident in GPE , ORG noted that the mother had taken the child to GPE on DATE supposedly for DATE , but had never returned .
The order in question authorised the father to confiscate the child ’s passport , once she crossed the NORP border , and to “ use all means ” to safeguard his parental rights .
In the second order ORG also imposed a prohibition on PERSON and her daughter leaving NORP territory . That measure , which was initially valid until DATE , was lifted on DATE .
On DATE ORG decided to adjourn its hearing in the divorce proceedings , which are still pending . PERSON is represented in those proceedings by CARDINAL members of ORG .

As a first step , PERSON lodged a criminal complaint in GPE against his wife for child abduction . The PERSON public prosecutor ’s office took no action , however , on the ground that the case fell to be dealt with under LAW and should be brought before the bodies having jurisdiction to deal with it .

Mr Chelouche therefore applied to ORG of his country , designated as ORG ( “ GPE ’s ORG ” ) , for assistance in securing his daughter ’s return to GPE , in accordance with the procedure laid down in DATE .
On DATE , for the purposes of those proceedings , GPE ’s ORG sent the CARDINAL aforementioned orders of ORG to its NORP counterpart , namely , ORG at ORG ( “ GPE ’s ORG ” ) .

On DATE GPE ’s ORG instructed the PERSON public prosecutor ( “ the public prosecutor ” ) to ascertain the child ’s current address , apply to ORG for an order prohibiting her from leaving NORP territory , and to summon PERSON in order to obtain a statement from her about the alleged abduction .
On DATE the ORG decided , in case no . CARDINAL , to issue the order requested by the public prosecutor , and gave instructions for the border posts to be informed accordingly .

On DATE GPE ’s ORG was sent CARDINAL further applications by the NORP authorities claiming that , under LAW , custody rights should be withdrawn from PERSON as ORG had found her liable for “ child abduction ” .

GPE ’s ORG then instructed the public prosecutor to raise a preliminary question in case no . CARDINAL pending before ORG , requesting the court not to rule on the custody of the child pending the outcome of the dispute regarding her return to GPE . On DATE the ORG followed the public prosecutor ’s advice and withdrew PERSON custody of her daughter .
On DATE friendly - settlement negotiations , conducted at the request of GPE ’s ORG and under the aegis of ORG , failed after PERSON insisted on his daughter ’s repatriation .
On DATE GPE ’s ORG sent PERSON lawyer a request from the NORP authorities regarding the arrangements proposed by PERSON for visiting his daughter in GPE .
On DATE the public prosecutor brought proceedings in ORG for the return of the child to her father ( case no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) .
ORG held CARDINAL hearings in the case .

At the hearing on DATE the parties submitted their preliminary observations . Counsel for PERSON argued that LAW was inapplicable in a number of respects to the case in hand and produced in support of that submission private legal opinions by NORP professors of private international law and NORP lawyers .

With a view to proving that the child was socially integrated in GPE and had ties there , PERSON also relied on numerous documents and witness statements , and asserted that the girl had gone with her to GPE with the father ’s consent and could not therefore be regarded as having been abducted .
PERSON , for his part , disputed those submissions and called CARDINAL witnesses : his uncle and mother .
At the end of the hearing the court fixed the father ’s visiting DATE . The visits were to take place at the mother ’s home in the presence of a social worker , but without the mother being present .

At the following hearing , on DATE , which was the last one , ORG first took formal note of the documents produced by GPE ’s ORG in support of Mr Chelouche ’s application . These were statements from nurseries and paediatricians in GPE . Also produced in the proceedings was an official record of the dates on which the child had gone in and out of GPE during the period DATE , drawn up by the GPE city authorities and the NORP and NORP border police .

During the proceedings Mr Chelouche , referring in particular to the information provided by ORG , claimed that his daughter had spent PERCENT of her life in GPE . He submitted that his right was established and that a ruling had to be made expeditiously , since LAW required proceedings to be disposed of within DATE .

The court then heard evidence from Mr Chelouche ’s mother and uncle and from the defendant ’s CARDINAL witnesses . According to the latter , the child and her mother had mainly spent their time in GPE , with the father ’s knowledge . The first applicant also produced a written statement to that effect by Mr PERSON , an NORP importer known to the couple .

PERSON relied further on photocopies of her passport , declaring that she had never stayed in GPE for DATE out of CARDINAL and had always had her daughter with her . She also submitted several ORG opinions questioning PERSON ’s ability to assume custody of his daughter .

In addition , PERSON challenged the participation of a public prosecutor in the proceedings and complained that the plaintiff was attempting to influence the court by referring to observations of ORG that were not based on any final judicial and binding decision awarding custody of the child to the father , that right having previously been exercised jointly by the parents in GPE .

Lastly , PERSON submitted a list of further witnesses . The public prosecutor opposed her application to call them , arguing that the case was ready for decision and that , in the light of the evidence , the court should find in favour of Mr Chelouche .
In accordance with LAW b ) , second paragraph , of LAW , ORG did not hear the second applicant on account of her young age .
At the end of the proceedings ORG decided that the child should be returned to her father in GPE , and maintained the prohibition on her leaving GPE until the judgment became final .

The court found that , whilst the parties to the dispute had joint custody of their daughter , PERSON had assured Mr Chelouche that she would go to GPE on DATE , as usual , and return on DATE , which she had not done in the end , contrary to the father ’s wishes . Having regard in particular to the official record provided by GPE ’s ORG , the court found that , during the period DATE , that is , until PERSON was removed , she had spent DATE outside GPE .
The other relevant passages from the judgment read as follows :

“ ... The ORG can not accept the argument submitted by the defendant and her representative that the child ’s habitual place of residence is not GPE . In the light of the CARDINAL - page official document issued by ORG ... setting out the dates of the child ’s entry into and exit from GPE DATE ... and the other documents ... , it is established that , from her birth onwards , the child spent most of her life in GPE . The assertion regarding the habitual place of residence is therefore inadmissible , particularly when regard is had to the fact that the defendant declared on DATE before the PERSON public prosecutor that she had lived in GPE for DATE that elapsed following the marriage . The child ’s habitual place of residence , prior to her removal , was therefore GPE , notwithstanding the contrary statements by the defendant ’s witnesses , which are not based on established facts and are contradicted by the official documents filed in the proceedings .

Nor can the ORG accept the final submission of the defendant ’s representative , based on LAW b ) of LAW , according to which the conditions for ordering the child ’s return are not satisfied on account of the state of war affecting GPE . It would appear that life in GPE pursues its normal course regarding , among other things , teaching , education , business , tourism , etc . , and that the conflict and disorder in the country are confined to certain specific regions . Moreover , the conflict , which is not new and has been going on for DATE , did not stop the parties from continuing to live in GPE . Furthermore , the existence of a grave risk , within the meaning of LAW ( b ) of LAW , that her return would expose the child to physical or psychological harm or otherwise place her in an intolerable situation has not been established . Thus , the conditions for refusing to return the child , as specified in the said LAW , have not been made out . ”
The judge of ORG concluded as follows :

“ ... After hearing the parties’ submissions , I consider it established that PERSON was taken to GPE by her mother and subsequently removed ... from her father , contrary to the latter ’s wishes , in breach of LAW ... I also consider it established that the requirements regarding the time - limit stipulated in LAW of [ that convention ] are satisfied , but that the conditions capable of justifying a refusal to return the child in the light of LAW and DATE are not . ”

On DATE , following the divorce proceedings instituted by her husband , PERSON applied to ORG ( ORG ) , using an NORP lawyer . The application , which was lodged on PERSON behalf , sought to challenge the jurisdiction of the religious courts on the ground that the mother was not an NORP national and did not reside in GPE .
However , after a thorough examination of the case another lawyer convinced the first applicant that the application “ stood no chance of success ” , and she withdrew it on DATE .

On DATE PERSON final application for reinstatement of custody of her daughter , in case no . CARDINAL , was dismissed by ORG , having regard to the order for the child ’s return in case no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL .

On DATE PERSON appealed on points of law against the decision to return the child to her father . Relying on the concept of the “ best interest of the child ” , she maintained that her daughter ’s habitual residence was in GPE . In her submission , a child could have several places of residence , under the rules of international law , and , in any event , LAW could not be applied merely by calculating DATE the child had spent in GPE .

The first applicant argued that the child could not therefore be considered to have been abducted , especially as the father had knowingly agreed to the child gradually settling in GPE ; PERSON had neither a fixed place of residence nor regular work commitments in GPE , and had himself been keen to settle elsewhere .

According to PERSON , he had in fact acted in bad faith in order to have the child ’s habitual residence established arbitrarily , deliberately referring the matter to a rabbinical court , which – despite having no jurisdiction – had ruled in the absence of the mother on the basis of religious tenets and with total disregard for the principles of equality of arms and adversarial process .
Lastly , PERSON lawyer referred to the prosecution ’s participation in the proceedings before ORG , alleging that this had considerably swayed the mind of the single judge of ORG .
On DATE ORG held a hearing at which it heard submissions from both parties’ representatives . On DATE it upheld all the provisions of the impugned judgment .
The applicant then lodged an application for rectification of a judgment .
On DATE , at the request of its NORP counterpart , GPE ’s ORG instructed the public prosecutor to take the necessary measures to prevent PERSON from leaving with the child .
On DATE PERSON application for rectification was refused and the judgment ordering the child ’s return thus became final .
On DATE Mr Chelouche brought enforcement proceedings for the return of his daughter .
Enforcement of the judgment was stayed , however , in accordance with the interim measure indicated in the case by ORG under Rule CARDINAL of the Rules of Court .

A report drawn up on DATE by the social worker responsible for overseeing the parental visits noted that PERSON had made efforts to ensure that the child ’s meetings with her father were conducted smoothly and in a warm atmosphere . A second report , filed in the proceedings on DATE , on the date when the judgment at first instance was delivered , still referred to a harmonious relationship between the child and her father .
However , the many further reports drawn up by social workers after that judgment were increasingly critical of the father .

On DATE , when visiting the child at PERSON flat , Mr ORG allegedly attacked the social worker present , insisting that he wanted to talk to his daughter alone . He allegedly also caused damage in the flat . A complaint lodged in connection with those events led to the institution of criminal proceedings , which are still pending .
It appears that relations deteriorated still further after that incident , and on DATE , at PERSON request , a second indictment was filed against Mr Chelouche .

Following a series of psychiatric examinations carried out in DATE and DATE , in the appropriate departments of CARDINAL university hospitals , the second applicant was diagnosed with post - traumatic stress disorder . She has been taking medication ever since .
For some of the provisions of this convention , see , for example , PERSON and GPE v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , § CARDINAL , ECHR CARDINAL-V ) . The following ORG are also relevant :

“ If ORG which receives an application referred to in DATE has reason to believe that the child is in another Contracting State , it shall directly and without delay transmit the application to ORG of that ORG and inform the requesting ORG , or the applicant , as the case may be . ”

“ In ascertaining whether there has been a wrongful removal or retention within the meaning of LAW , the judicial or administrative authorities of the requested ORG may take notice directly of the law of , and of judicial or administrative decisions , formally recognised or not in the ORG of the habitual residence of the child , without recourse to the specific procedures for the proof of that law or for the recognition of foreign decisions which would otherwise be applicable . ”

“ The judicial or administrative authorities of a Contracting ORG may , prior to the making of an order for the return of the child , request that the applicant obtain from the authorities of the ORG of the habitual residence of the child a decision or other determination that the removal or retention was wrongful within the meaning of LAW , where such a decision or determination may be obtained in that ORG . ORG shall so far as practicable assist applicants to obtain such a decision or determination . ”

“ After receiving notice of a wrongful removal or retention of a child in the sense of LAW , the judicial or administrative authorities of ORG to which the child has been removed or in which it has been retained shall not decide on the merits of rights of custody until it has been determined that the child is not to be returned under this LAW or unless an application under the LAW is not lodged within a reasonable time following receipt of the notice . ”

“ The return of the child under the provisions of LAW may be refused if this would not be permitted by the fundamental principles of the requested ORG relating to the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms . ”

“ Any application submitted to ORG or directly to the judicial or administrative authorities of a ORG in accordance with the terms of this Convention , together with documents and any other information appended thereto or provided by ORG , shall be admissible in the courts or administrative authorities of GPE . ”
The relevant provisions of this convention , ratified by GPE and by GPE on DATE and DATE respectively , provide :

“ In all actions concerning children , whether undertaken by public or private social welfare institutions , courts of law , administrative authorities or legislative bodies , the best interests of the child shall be a primary consideration . ”
“ GPE Parties undertake to respect the right of the child to preserve his or her identity , including nationality , name and family relations as recognised by law without unlawful interference . ”

“ CARDINAL . DATE States Parties shall ensure that a child shall not be separated from his or her parents against their will , except when competent authorities subject to judicial review determine , in accordance with applicable law and procedures , that such separation is necessary for the best interests of the child . Such determination may be necessary in a particular case such as CARDINAL involving abuse or neglect of the child by the parents , or one where the parents are living separately and a decision must be made as to the child ’s place of residence .

CARDINAL . NORP In any proceedings pursuant to paragraph CARDINAL of the present Article , all interested parties shall be given an opportunity to participate in the proceedings and make their views known .

CARDINAL . DATE States Parties shall respect the right of the child who is separated from one or both parents to maintain personal relations and direct contact with both parents on a regular basis , except if it is contrary to the child ’s best interests . ”

“ CARDINAL . In accordance with the obligation of GPE Parties under LAW , paragraph CARDINAL , applications by a child or his or her parents to enter or leave a ORG for the purpose of family reunification shall be dealt with by GPE Parties in a positive , humane and expeditious manner . GPE Parties shall further ensure that the submission of such a request shall entail no adverse consequences for the applicants and for the members of their family .

CARDINAL . A child whose parents reside in different GPE shall have the right to maintain on a regular basis , save in exceptional circumstances , personal relations and direct contacts with both parents . Towards that end and in accordance with the obligation of GPE Parties under LAW , paragraph CARDINAL , GPE Parties shall respect the right of the child and his or her parents to leave any country , including their own , and to enter their own country . The right to leave any country shall be subject only to such restrictions as are prescribed by law and which are necessary to protect the national security , public order ( ordre public ) , public health or morals or the rights and freedoms of others and are consistent with the other rights recognised in the present Convention . ”

“ CARDINAL . DATE States Parties shall assure to the child who is capable of forming his or her own views the right to express those views freely in all matters affecting the child , the views of the child being given due weight in accordance with the age and maturity of the child .

CARDINAL . NORP For this purpose , the child shall in particular be provided the opportunity to be heard in any judicial and administrative proceedings affecting the child , either directly , or through a representative or an appropriate body , in a manner consistent with the procedural rules of national law . ”
LAW , signed by GPE on DATE and ratified by GPE on DATE , provides :
“ CARDINAL . The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to protection by society and the ORG .

CARDINAL . GPE Parties to the present LAW shall take appropriate steps to ensure equality of rights and responsibilities of spouses as to marriage , during marriage and at its dissolution . In the case of dissolution , provision shall be made for the necessary protection of any children . ”
GPE ’s reservation regarding that provision reads as follows :

“ With reference to LAW , and any other provision thereof to which the present reservation may be relevant , matters of personal status are governed in GPE by the religious law of the parties concerned .
To the extent that such law is inconsistent with its obligations under the LAW , GPE reserves the right to apply that law . ”

Implementation of the LAW by the GPE Parties is supervised by ORG , which is a body made up of independent experts . Under LAW , the ORG may examine communications of GPE Parties in respect of other GPE . All the GPE Parties undertake to submit reports , at regular intervals , on the measures they have adopted which give effect to the rights recognised in the LAW . They must submit an initial report within DATE of acceding to the LAW and subsequently whenever the ORG requests CARDINAL . ORG studies the reports and informs ORG concerned of its concerns and recommendations in the form of “ final observations ” . ORG meets in GPE or GPE and generally holds CARDINAL sessions per year .
Recommendation CARDINAL ( DATE ) of ORG of ORG on a NORP Charter on the Rights of the LOC states among the first general principles :
“ ( a ) Children must no longer be considered as GPE property , but must be recognised as individuals with their own rights and needs ; ”

LAW has statutory force in NORP law and forms part of the legislation . In theory , the execution in GPE of a decision of a foreign court requires a registration procedure . However , by virtue of LAW , decisions delivered by the courts of the place of “ habitual residence ” of the child concerned are applicable without any need for a registration procedure . When dealing with an application under LAW , the NORP family affairs courts are therefore empowered to rely directly on the court decision on which the application is based as conclusive evidence ( LAW ) , without having to endorse it in the legal sense of the term .

Execution of a decision to return a child to the country deemed to be its “ habitual residence ” is carried out by public prosecutors , on behalf of ORG at ORG , that is , “ the ORG ” designated to implement the procedures laid down in LAW .

In practice , in that context , the public prosecutor in charge of execution asks the requesting ORG to inform him of the date of arrival of the parent whose child has been abducted and makes the necessary arrangements for the child to be returned in the best conditions .

In accordance with LAW b ) of LAW , procedures for the return of a child and meetings in person with a child are conducted in the presence of an expert ( social worker , teacher , psychologist , etc . ) who is appointed jointly by the head of ORG and ORG and ORG .

The Law of DATE , which establishes the structure of the NORP legal system , provides – apart from the special courts – for CARDINAL major types of court : civil , religious and military . The religious courts are governed by ORG Act ( Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . The laws applicable to NORP in the sphere of personal status are generally based on the NORP and the Halacha .

For parties of the NORP faith , the regional rabbinical courts ( ORG ) have exclusive jurisdiction in the areas of , among other things , divorce , marriage and diet of the members of their community . They also have jurisdiction in any other sphere relating to the personal status of NORP ( such as custody and contact rights in respect of children , maintenance payments , filiation , etc . ) . Moreover , in respect of those matters , the regional rabbinical courts and the civil family courts ( ORG ) DATE which are governed by FAC ( Law no . CARDINAL ) DATE are vested with concurrent jurisdiction , which , in practice , becomes exclusive for the court before which the case is first brought .
Decisions of the rabbinical courts delivered at first instance are subject to review by ORG ( PERSON ) , which is the appeal court .

Whether a case is tried by the rabbinical or the civil courts , the final court of appeal is ORG . According to the information in the ORG ’s possession , however , in respect of the rabbinical courts ORG acts as ORG , under section CARDINAL(c ) of the above - mentioned PERSON of DATE , and , accordingly , the object and scope of its power of review are more limited . In practice , it would appear that this power of review is often exercised in respect of disputes relating to the jurisdiction of the rabbinical courts and , more rarely , in cases of denial of natural rights and non - application of the mandatory provisions of civil law . It is accepted that , in cases of conflict of jurisdiction , ORG can set aside the decision of the rabbinical court and refer the case to a civil court , but that , where errors of law with regard to the Halacha are concerned , it will merely remit the case to the original rabbinical court for it alone to amend its decision .

Many NORP writers point to the inequality between the sexes in the rabbinical courts , particularly in connection with the get institution , which is often criticised by NORP society . In accordance with the Halacha , only the husband may petition for divorce from his wife , by handing her the get . There is a consensual aspect to the measure , however , since the wife is free to accept or refuse the get .

Under NORP law , the family courts and the rabbinical courts can , in the interests of the proper conduct of the proceedings , prohibit a party to divorce proceedings from leaving NORP territory . According to the information available , such ne exeat measures are ordered by the rabbinical courts at the request of the party petitioning for divorce , normally for a renewable DATE period . Where the respondent is not an NORP national , the measure is applied with particular rigour . Where the opposing party objects , the rabbinical court determines the matter following a hearing of the issue .
